awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Personalized Proactive Diabetes Self-Management and Social Networking for American Indians
awd_abstract_narration:
The epidemic of diabetes in American Indian (AI) communities is a serious public health challenge. As daily diabetes care is primarily handled by the patients and their families, the effectiveness of diabetes control is largely impacted by self-care strategies and behaviors. This project proposes a proactive diabetes self-care mobile platform based on the unique socio-economic, cultural, and geographical status of AI patients living in a reservation community in the upper Midwest. The mobile platform connects AI diabetic patients to their medical devices, healthcare team and similar patients, and offers personalized prediction, recommendation, and social networking regarding diabetes care. It transforms diabetes management from the traditional reactive and hospital-centered care to preventive, proactive, evidence-based, and person-centered care. This project will also provide valuable research opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students, especially from underrepresented populations.


The goal of the project is to develop an integrated, accessible, cost-effective solution for improved diabetes self-management and social networking for AI patients. Considering the quasi-ubiquitous use of cellphones in most AI communities, a cellphone-based platform is proposed to provide smart and personalized service. A biocultural ontology is developed to model the unique characteristics of AI patients. Based on a user's ontological profile, through ontology-based reasoning and machine learning approaches, personalized prediction and recommendation are delivered to the AI patient. Semantics-based social matching is applied as a technical and intellectual framework for connecting AI patients with similarities to form online peer support communities. Personalized self-managed trust and privacy mechanisms are developed to establish secure user relationships. To improve system usability, a multimodal interface is implemented to deliver information with appropriate input and output modalities to a user based on the user's physical and social context.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project has yielded significant outcomes in the field of diabetes self-management for American Indian populations. Over the course of the project, the following achievements and outcomes have been realized: (1) Innovative Diabetes Management Solutions: The project successfully designed and implemented a personalized proactive diabetes self-management system tailored specifically for American Indian patients. This system incorporates cultural sensitivity and user-centric design, addressing the unique needs of this population. (2) Healthcare Disparity Reduction: The research conducted within this project has contributed to reducing healthcare disparities among American Indian communities. By providing culturally appropriate healthcare solutions and improving health literacy, the project has worked towards achieving more equitable healthcare outcomes. (3) Community Engagement: The project prioritized community engagement, involving American Indian community members as active participants in the research process. This approach has empowered communities, built trust, and promoted their active involvement in shaping healthcare solutions. (4) STEM Outreach and Education: The project has made significant contributions to STEM outreach and education. By inspiring interest in science and technology among underrepresented groups, it has contributed to the diversification of the STEM workforce. (5) Improved Health Literacy: The use of artificial intelligence to simplify medical information has contributed to improved health literacy among the general public, enhancing their understanding of healthcare information.In summary, this project has made significant strides in addressing the healthcare needs of American Indian populations while simultaneously promoting community engagement, diversity, and equity in healthcare. The outcomes of this research have the potential to impact not only American Indian communities but also the broader healthcare landscape and underserved populations worldwide.


Last Modified: 09/21/2023
Modified by: Juan Li
